Delimiters are printed without framing white space. If no value component is provided, the delimiter appears as a line break.
1 CTY municipality

The name of the city, town, village, or other community or delivery center
1 POB post box

A numbered box located in a post station.
1 ZIP postal code

A postal code designating a region defined by the postal service.
1 PRE precinct

A subsection of a municipality
1 STA state or province

A sub-unit of a country with limited sovereignty in a federally organized country.

Addresses are conceptualized as text with added mark-up. The mark-up may break the address into lines and may describe in detail the role of each address part if it is known. Address parts occur in the address in the order in which they would be printed on a mailing label. The model is similar to HTML or XML markup of text.

 2.18.12.1XML Representation

partType is represented simultaneously in Element and Attribute forms. In the Element form, the name of the element is determined by the part type, as specified in AddressPartType Element Names below. Additionally, each such element has an XML attribute partType whose value, if present, must be a valid value from the domain AddressPartType (Concept Domain AddressPartType. ValueSet OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.11.10642. CodeSystem "AddressPartType", OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.5.16, Owner: HL7) corresponding to the part type represented by the element on which it appears. Since the XML attribute partType always has a fixed value, it is not normally present in the XML instance. There is a special element "part" which is used to represent an unknown part type. The "part" element has no XML attribute partType - partType is NullFlavor.NI.

AddressPartType Element Names
Element Name Part Type Associated Domain
addressLine AL
additionalLocator ADL
unitID UNID
unitType UNIT AddressPartUnitType
deliveryAddressLine DAL
deliveryInstallationType DINST AddressPartDeliveryInstallationType
deliveryInstallationArea DINSTA
deliveryInstallationQualifier DINSTQ
deliveryMode DMOD AddressPartDeliveryMode
deliveryModeIdentifier DMODID
streetAddressLine SAL
houseNumber BNR
buildingNumberSuffix BNS
postBox POB
houseNumberNumeric BNN
streetName STR
streetNameBase STB
streetNameType STTYP AddressPartStreetType
direction DIR AddressPartDirection
intersection INT
careOf CAR
censusTract CEN
country CNT AddressPartCountry
county CPA AddressPartCounty
city CTY AddressPartCity
delimiter DEL
precinct PRE
state STA AddressPartState
postalCode ZIP
part NullFlavor.NI
 2.18.13Examples

See the examples in Examples.

 2.19Postal Address (AD) -->

Definition:      Mailing and home or office addresses. A sequence of address parts, such as street or post office Box, city, postal code, country, etc.

AD is primarily used to communicate data that will allow printing mail labels, that will allow a person to physically visit that address. The postal address data type is not supposed to be a container for additional information that might be useful for finding geographic locations (e.g., GPS coordinates) or for performing epidemiological studies. Such additional information is captured by other, more appropriate HL7 elements.

Structurally, the postal address data type is a sequence of address part values with an added "use" code and a valid time range for information about if and when the address can be used for a given purpose.

Components of Postal Address
Name Type Description
use DSET<CS> A set of codes advising a system or user which address in a set of like addresses to select for a given purpose.
useablePeriod GTS A GTS specifying the periods of time during which the address can be used. This is used to specify different addresses for different times of the year or to refer to historical addresses.
isNotOrdered BL A boolean value specifying whether the order of the address parts is known or not. While the address parts are always a Sequence, the order in which they are presented may or may not be known. Where this matters, isNotOrdered can be used to convey this information.
 2.19.1XML Representation

AD is represented by an XML element whose name is determined by the context in which it is used. The element has attributes and child elements as described in the template and the sub-sections below.

 2.19.2template
<!-- type AD -->
<x
   nullFlavor = ( NI | INV | OTH | NINF | PINF | UNC | DER | UNK | ASKU | NAV | QS | NASK | TRC | MSK | NA )
   flavorId = ST*
   updateMode = (A | D | R | AR | N | U | K)
   isNotOrdered = BL
   use = CS*
   >
   Content: ( ( delimiter | country | state | county | city | postalCode | addressLine | streetAddressLine |
                houseNumber | houseNumberNumeric | direction | streetName | streetNameBase |
                streetNameType | additionalLocator | unitID | unitType | intersection | careOf | censusTract |
                deliveryAddressLine | deliveryInstallationType | deliveryInstallationArea |
                deliveryInstallationQualifier | deliveryMode | deliveryModeIdentifier |
                buildingNumberSuffix | postBox | precinct | part | #PCDATA )*, useablePeriod* )
</x>

Any non whitespace text in the AD content is interpreted as ADXP parts with a null partType. Refer to the the Formatting Address section (2.21.1.5) in Abstract Data Types Specification for full details on interpretation of AD content.

 2.19.3Use : DSET<CS>

Definition:      A set of codes advising a system or user which address in a set of like addresses to select for a given purpose.

The postal address use codes are defined by the PostalAddressUse domain (Concept Domain PostalAddressUse. ValueSet OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.11.190. CodeSystem "PostalAddressUse", OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.5.1012, Owner: HL7).

Concept Domain PostalAddressUse. ValueSet OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.11.190. CodeSystem "PostalAddressUse", OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.5.1012, Owner: HL7
lvl code name definition
1 -- AddressUse
2  H home address

A communication address at a home, attempted contacts for business purposes might intrude privacy and chances are one will contact family or other household members instead of the person one wishes to call. Typically used with urgent cases, or if no other contacts are available.

3   HP primary home

The primary home, to reach a person after business hours.
3   HV vacation home

A vacation home, to reach a person while on vacation.
2  WP work place

An office address. First choice for business related contacts during business hours.
3   DIR Direct

Indicates a work place address or telecommunication address that reaches the individual or organization directly without intermediaries. For phones, often referred to as a 'private line'.

3   PUB Public

Indicates a work place address or telecommunication address that is a 'standard' address which may reach a reception service, mail-room, or other intermediary prior to the target entity.

2  BAD bad address

A flag indicating that the address is bad, in fact, useless.
2  TMP temporary address

A temporary address, may be good for visit or mailing. Note that an address history can provide more detailed information.
2  PHYS physical visit address

Used primarily to visit an address.
2  PST postal address

Used to send mail.
1 -- AddressRepresentationUse

Identifies the different representations of a Address. The representation may affect how the address is used. (E.g. use of Ideographic for formal communications.)

2  ABC Alphabetic

Alphabetic transcription of name (Japanese: romaji)
2  IDE Ideographic

Ideographic representation of name (e.g., Japanese kanji, Chinese characters)
2  SYL Syllabic

Syllabic transcription of name (e.g., Japanese kana, Korean hangul)
1 SRCH Search Type Uses

A name intended for use in searching or matching.
2  SNDX Soundex

An address spelled according to the SoundEx algorithm.
2  PHON phonetic

The address as understood by the data enterer, i.e. a close approximation of a phonetic spelling of the address, not based on a phonetic algorithm.

The postal address use code is not a complete classification for locations or activities that take place at these locations. Its main purpose is to suggest or discourage the use of a particular address. The use code should not be considered in isolation. The data element in which the address appears (class and attribute) and the context to other data may express the precise nature and use of the address more appropriately than a use code.

 2.19.3.1XML Representation

use is represented by the XML attribute use whose value, if present, must be 0 or more valid values from the PostalAddressUse domain (Concept Domain PostalAddressUse. ValueSet OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.11.190. CodeSystem "PostalAddressUse", OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.5.1012, Owner: HL7) separated by whitespace.

 2.19.4Useable Period : GTS

Definition:      A GTS specifying the periods of time during which the address can be used. This is used to specify different addresses for different times of the year or to refer to historical addresses.

 2.19.4.1XML Representation

useablePeriod is represented by 0 or more XML elements useablePeriod each of which must be a valid GTS.

 2.19.5Is Not Ordered : BL

Definition:      A boolean value specifying whether the order of the address parts is known or not. While the address parts are always a Sequence, the order in which they are presented may or may not be known. Where this matters, isNotOrdered can be used to convey this information.

 2.19.5.1XML Representation

isNotOrdered is represented by the XML attribute isNotOrdered whose value, if present, must be a valid BL.

 2.19.6Examples

The following are examples of addresses in an XML encoded form, where the XML tag is the address part type and the data content is the address part value.

The address:

1050 W Wishard Blvd,
RG 5th floor,
Indianapolis, IN 46240

can be encoded in any of the following forms:

The first form would result from a system that only stores addresses as free text or in a list of fields line1, line2, etc.:

 2.19.6.1example
<addr use='WP'>
   1050 W Wishard Blvd,
   RG 5th floor,
   Indianapolis, IN 46240
</addr>

The second form is more specific about the role of the address parts than the first one and is the typical form seen in the U.S., where street address is sometimes separated, and city, state and ZIP code are always separated.

 2.19.6.2example
<addr use='WP'>
   <streetAddressLine>1050 W Wishard Blvd</streetAddressLine>,
   <streetAddressLine>RG 5th floor</streetAddressLine>,
   <city>Indianapolis</city>, <state>IN</state>
   <postalCode>46240</postalCode>
</addr>

The third is even more specific:

 2.19.6.3example
<addr use='WP'>
   <houseNumber>1050</houseNumber>
   <direction>W</direction>
   <streetName>Wishard Blvd</streetName>,
   <additionalLocator>RG 5th floor</additionalLocator>,
   <city>Indianapolis</city>, <state>IN</state>
   <postalCode>46240</postalCode>
</addr>

The latter form above is not often used in the USA. However, it is useful in Germany, where many systems keep house number as a distinct field. For example, the German address:

Windsteiner Weg 54a,
D-14165 Berlin

would most likely be encoded as follows:

 2.19.6.4example
<addr use='HP'>
   <streetName>Windsteiner Weg</streetName>
   <houseNumber>54a</houseNumber>,<delimiter/>
   <country>D</country>-<postalCode>14165</postalCode>
   <city>Berlin</city>
</addr>
 2.20Entity Name Part (ENXP) -->

Definition:      A character string token representing a part of a name. May have a type code signifying the role of the part in the whole entity name, and a qualifier code for more detail about the name part type. Typical name parts for person names are given names, and family names, titles, etc.

Components of Entity Name Part
Name Type Description
data XML Text Content The data itself represented in the XML instance encoding.
value ST The plain text data. Note that plain text content may appear in either the value attribute or the text content of the element, but not both.
code ST A code symbol the identifies the part in some concept coding system.
codeSystem UID Specifies the code system that defines the code.
codeSystemName ST A common name for the coding system.
codeSystemVersion ST If applicable, a version descriptor defined specifically for the given code system.
displayName ST A name, title, or representation for the code as it exists in the code system identified by the value of codeSystem. Often, but not always, this is the same as the data of the part.
partType CS Indicates whether the name part is a given name, family name, prefix, suffix, etc.
qualifier DSET<CS> qualifier is a set of codes each of which specifies a certain subcategory of the name part in addition to the main name part type. For example, a given name may be flagged as a nickname, a family name may be a pseudonym or a name of public records.
 2.20.1XML Representation

ENXP is represented as an XML element whose name is derived from the entity name part type code (see table below) and whose content is just like an ST, except that it also has XML attribute partType and XML attribute qualifier as described above. The value of the XML attribute partType is fixed to the appropriate name part type. The XML attribute partType is generally not used.

 2.20.2template
<!-- type ENXP -->
<family
   nullFlavor = ( NI | INV | OTH | NINF | PINF | UNC | DER | UNK | ASKU | NAV | QS | NASK | TRC | MSK | NA )
   flavorId = ST*
   updateMode = (A | D | R | AR | N | U | K)
   value = ST
   language = CS
   partType = (FAM): FAM
   qualifier = CS*
   >
   Content: ( #PCDATA )
</family>

<given
   nullFlavor = ( NI | INV | OTH | NINF | PINF | UNC | DER | UNK | ASKU | NAV | QS | NASK | TRC | MSK | NA )
   flavorId = ST*
   updateMode = (A | D | R | AR | N | U | K)
   value = ST
   language = CS
   partType = (GIV) : GIV
   qualifier = CS*
   >
   Content: ( #PCDATA )
</given>

<prefix
   nullFlavor = ( NI | INV | OTH | NINF | PINF | UNC | DER | UNK | ASKU | NAV | QS | NASK | TRC | MSK | NA )
   flavorId = ST*
   updateMode = (A | D | R | AR | N | U | K)
   value = ST
   language = CS
   code = ST
   codeSystem = UID
   codeSystemName = ST
   codeSystemVersion = ST
   displayName = ST
   partType = (PFX) : PFX
   qualifier = CS*
   >
   Content: ( #PCDATA )
</prefix>

<suffix
   nullFlavor = ( NI | INV | OTH | NINF | PINF | UNC | DER | UNK | ASKU | NAV | QS | NASK | TRC | MSK | NA )
   flavorId = ST*
   updateMode = (A | D | R | AR | N | U | K)
   value = ST
   language = CS
   code = ST
   codeSystem = UID
   codeSystemName = ST
   codeSystemVersion = ST
   displayName = ST
   partType = (SFX) : SFX
   qualifier = CS*
   >
   Content: ( #PCDATA )
</suffix>

<title
   nullFlavor = ( NI | INV | OTH | NINF | PINF | UNC | DER | UNK | ASKU | NAV | QS | NASK | TRC | MSK | NA )
   flavorId = ST*
   updateMode = (A | D | R | AR | N | U | K)
   value = ST
   language = CS
   code = ST
   codeSystem = UID
   codeSystemName = ST
   codeSystemVersion = ST
   displayName = ST
   partType = (TITLE) : TITLE
   qualifier = CS*
   >
   Content: ( #PCDATA )
</title>

<delimiter
   nullFlavor = ( NI | INV | OTH | NINF | PINF | UNC | DER | UNK | ASKU | NAV | QS | NASK | TRC | MSK | NA )
   flavorId = ST*
   updateMode = (A | D | R | AR | N | U | K)
   value = ST
   language = CS
   partType = (DEL) : DEL
   qualifier = CS*
   >
   Content: ( #PCDATA )
</delimiter>
 2.20.3Data : XML Text Content (inherited from BIN)

Definition:      The data itself represented in the XML instance encoding.

 2.20.4XML Representation

is represented as the text content of the XML element representing the ENXP value.

 2.20.5Value : ST (inherited from ED)

Definition:      The plain text data. Note that plain text content may appear in either the value attribute or the text content of the element, but not both.

 2.20.6XML Representation

value is represented by the XML attribute value.

The R2B ITS allows ST data to appear in either the text content of the ED element, or in the value attribute. This is to allow gradual transition to this change which occured in ITS R2 (ISO 21090 Healthcare Data Types) and to ease alignment with ongoing RIM changes. New instances MAY have text content, or the value attribute. Instances SHALL NOT have both values populated. Conformant applications SHALL accept either the text or value attribute. (Note: for XSLT, this can be done using (text()|@value) in place of text().)

 2.20.7Code : ST

Definition:      A code symbol the identifies the part in some concept coding system.

 2.20.7.1XML Representation

code is represented by the XML attribute code whose value, if present, must be a valid code from the designated code system.

 2.20.8Code System : UID

Definition:      Specifies the code system that defines the code.

 2.20.8.1XML Representation

codeSystem is represented by the XML attribute codeSystem whose value, if present, must be a valid UID.

 2.20.9Code System Name : ST

Definition:      A common name for the coding system.

 2.20.9.1XML Representation

codeSystemName is represented by the XML attribute codeSystemName whose value, if present, must be a valid ST.

 2.20.10Code System Version : ST

Definition:      If applicable, a version descriptor defined specifically for the given code system.

 2.20.10.1XML Representation

codeSystemVersion is represented by the XML attribute codeSystemVersion whose value, if present, must be a valid ST.

 2.20.11Display Name : ST

Definition:      A name, title, or representation for the code as it exists in the code system identified by the value of codeSystem. Often, but not always, this is the same as the data of the part.

 2.20.11.1XML Representation

displayName is represented by the XML attribute displayName whose value, if present, must be a valid ST.

 2.20.12Name Part Type : CS

Definition:      Indicates whether the name part is a given name, family name, prefix, suffix, etc.

Entity name part types are as defined in Concept Domain EntityNamePartType2B. ValueSet OID: [tbd]. CodeSystem "", OID: [tbd], Owner: HL7

Concept Domain EntityNamePartType2B. ValueSet OID: [tbd]. CodeSystem "", OID: [tbd], Owner: HL7
lvl code name definition
1 FAM family Family name, this is the name that links to the genealogy. In some cultures (e.g. Eritrea) the family name of a son is the first name of his father.
1 GIV given Given name (don't call it "first name" since this given names do not always come first)
1 PFX prefix A prefix has a strong association to the immediately following name part. A prefix has no implicit trailing white space (it has implicit leading white space though). Note that prefixes can be inverted.
1 SFX suffix A suffix has a strong association to the immediately preceding name part. A suffix has no implicit leading white space (it has implicit trailing white space though). Suffices can not be inverted.
1 DEL delimiter A delimiter has no meaning other than being literally printed in this name representation. A delimiter has no implicit leading and trailing white space.
1 TITLE Title Part of the name that is acquired as a title due to academic, legal, employment or nobility status etc.

Not every name part must have a type code, if the type code is unknown, not applicable, or simply undefined this is expressed by a null value (type.isNull). For example, a name may be "Rogan Sulma" and it may not be clear which one is a given name or which is a last name, or whether Rogan may be a title.

Entity names are conceptualized as text with added mark-up. The mark-up may describe in detail the role of each name part if it is known. Name parts occur in the order in which they would be printed on a mailing label. The model is similar to HTML or XML markup of text.

Backwards Compatibility Note: In R2, the Entity Name Part Type and Entity Name Part Qualifiers coding scheme were reworked in a not backward compatible way. The most important change was that prefix and suffix were moved from part types to qualifiers, and title was moved from a qualifier to a part type. This specification handles this by making prefix, suffix, and title both part types and qualifiers. Implementations SHALL convert from the R1 form (prefix/suffix as part types) to the R2 form (title as a part type with prefix/suffix as qualifiers) when performing logical operations on the data.

 2.20.12.1XML Representation

partType is represented simultaneously in Element and Attribute forms. In the Element form, the name of the element is determined by the part type, as specified in EntityNamePartType Element Names below. Additionally, each such element has an XML attribute partType whose value, if present, must be a valid value from the domain EntityNamePartType () corresponding to the part type represented by the element on which it appears. Since the XML attribute partType always has a fixed value, it is not normally present in the XML instance. There is a special element "part" which is used to represent an unknown part type, so that qualifiers may be associated with the part. The "part" element has no XML attribute partType - partType is NullFlavor.NI.

EntityNamePartType Element Names
Element Name Part Type Associated Domain
delimiter DEL
family FAM
given GIV
prefix PFX EntityNamePrefix
suffix SFX EntityNameSuffix
title TITLE EntityNamePrefix or EntityNameSuffix
part NullFlavor.NI
 2.20.13Qualifier : DSET<CS>

Definition:     qualifier is a set of codes each of which specifies a certain subcategory of the name part in addition to the main name part type. For example, a given name may be flagged as a nickname, a family name may be a pseudonym or a name of public records.

Entity name part qualifiers are as defined in Concept Domain EntityNamePartQualifier2B. ValueSet OID: [tbd]. CodeSystem "", OID: [tbd], Owner: HL7

Concept Domain EntityNamePartQualifier2B. ValueSet OID: [tbd]. CodeSystem "", OID: [tbd], Owner: HL7
lvl code name definition
1 LS Legal status

For organizations a suffix indicating the legal status, e.g., "Inc.", "Co.", "AG", "GmbH", "B.V." "S.A.", "Ltd." etc.
1 BR Birth

A name that a person was given at birth or established as a consequence of adoption.

Note: this is not used for temporary names assigned at birth such as “Baby of Smith” – which is just a name with a use code of “TEMP”.

1 AD Acquired

A name part a person acquired.

The name part may be acquired by adoption, or the person may have chosen to use the name part for some other reason.

Note: this differs from an Other/Psuedonym/Alias in that an acquired name part is acquired on a formal basis rather than an informal one (e.g. registered as part of the official name).

2  SP Spouse

The name assumed from the partner in a marital relationship. Usually the spouse's family name. Note that no inference about gender can be made from the existence of spouse names.

1 MID Middle Name

Indicates that the name part is a middle name.

Usage Notes:

In general, the english ‘middle name’ concept is all of the given names after the first. This qualifier may be used to explicitly indicate which given names are considered to be middle names.

The middle name qualifier may also be used with family names. This is a Scandinavian use case, matching the concept of “mellomnavn” / “mellannamn”. Note that there are specific rules that indicate what names may be taken as a mellannamn in different Scandinavian countries

1 CL callme

Callme is used to indicate which of the various name parts is used when interacting with the person.
1 IN Initial

Indicates that a name part is just an initial. Initials do not imply a trailing period since this would not work with non-Latin scripts. In some languages, initials may consist of more than one letter, e.g., "Ph" could stand for "Philippe" or "Th" For "Thomas".

1 PFX Prefix

A prefix has a strong association to the immediately following name part. A prefix has no implicit trailing white space (it has implicit leading white space though).

1 SFX Suffix

A suffix has a strong association to the immediately preceding name part. A suffix has no implicit leading white space (it has implicit trailing white space though).

1 -- TitleStyles

Extra information about the style of a title.
2  AC Academic

Indicates that a title like "Dr." or a suffix like "M.D." or "Ph.D." is an academic title.
2  PR Professional

Primarily in the British Imperial culture people tend to have an abbreviation of their professional organization as part of their credential titles.

2  NB Nobility

A nobility title such as Sir, Count, Grafin.
2  HON Honorific

A honorific such as "The Right Honourable" or "Weledelgeleerde Heer".
2  VV voorvoegsel

A Dutch "voorvoegsel" is something like "van" or "de" that might have indicated nobility in the past but no longer so. Similar prefixes exist in other languages such as Spanish, French or Portugese.

1 TITLE title

Indicates that a prefix or a suffix is a title that applies to the whole name, not just the adjacent name part.
1 AD adopted

The name the person was given at the time of adoption.
 2.20.13.1XML Representation

qualifier is represented as the XML attribute qualifier whose value, if present, must be 0 or more values from the EntityNamePartQualifier domain () separated by whitespace.

 2.20.14Examples

See the examples in Examples, Examples and Examples.

 2.21Entity Name (EN) -->

Definition:      A name for a person, organization, place or thing. A sequence of name parts, such as given name or family name, prefix, suffix, etc. Examples for entity name values are "Jim Bob Walton, Jr.", "Health Level Seven, Inc.", "Lake Tahoe", etc. An entity name may be as simple as a character string or may consist of several entity name parts, such as, "Jim", "Bob", "Walton", and "Jr.", "Health Level Seven" and "Inc.", "Lake" and "Tahoe".

Structurally, the entity name data type is a sequence of entity name part values with an added "use" code and a valid time range for information about if and when the name can be used for a given purpose.

Components of Entity Name
Name Type Description
use DSET<CS> A set of codes advising a system or user which name in a set of like names to select for a given purpose. A name without specific use code might be a default name useful for any purpose, but a name with a specific use code would be preferred for that respective purpose.
validTime IVL<TS> An interval of time specifying the time during which the name is or was used for the entity. This accomodates the fact that people change names for people, places and things.
 2.21.1XML Representation

EN is represented by an XML element whose name is determined by the context in which it is used. The element has attributes and child elements as described in the template and the sub-sections below.

 2.21.2template
<!-- type EN -->
<x
   nullFlavor = ( NI | INV | OTH | NINF | PINF | UNC | DER | UNK | ASKU | NAV | QS | NASK | TRC | MSK | NA )
   flavorId = ST*
   updateMode = (A | D | R | AR | N | U | K)
   use = CS*
   >
   Content: ( (delimiter | family | given | prefix | suffix | title | part | #PCDATA)*, validTime )
</x>

Any non whitespace text in the EN content is interpreted as ENXP parts with a null partType. Refer to the the Formatting Name section (2.23.1.4) in Abstract Data Types Specification for full details on interpretation of EN content.

 2.21.3Use : DSET<CS>

Definition:      A set of codes advising a system or user which name in a set of like names to select for a given purpose. A name without specific use code might be a default name useful for any purpose, but a name with a specific use code would be preferred for that respective purpose.

The entity names use codes are defined by the EntityNameUse domain (Concept Domain EntityNameUse. ValueSet OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.1.11.15913. CodeSystem "", OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.5.45, Owner: HL7).

Concept Domain EntityNameUse. ValueSet OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.1.11.15913. CodeSystem "", OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.5.45, Owner: HL7
lvl code name definition
1 -- NameRepresentationUse

Identifies the different representations of a name. The representation may affect how the name is used. (E.g. use of Ideographic for formal communications.)

2  ABC Alphabetic

Alphabetic transcription of name (Japanese: romaji)
2  IDE Ideographic

Ideographic representation of name (e.g., Japanese kanji, Chinese characters)
2  SYL Syllabic

Syllabic transcription of name (e.g., Japanese kana, Korean hangul)
1 C License

As recorded on a license, record, certificate, etc. (only if different from legal name)
1 L Legal

Known as/conventional/the one you use
1 ASGN assigned

A name assigned to a person. Reasons some organizations assign alternate names may include not knowing the person's name, or to maintain anonymity. Some, but not necessarily all, of the name types that people call "alias" may fit into this category.

1 I Indigenous/Tribal

e.g. Chief Red Cloud
1 P pseudonym

A self asserted name that the person is using or has used.
2  A Artist/Stage

Includes writer's pseudonym, stage name, etc
1 R Religious

e.g. Sister Mary Francis, Brother John
1 OR Official Registry

the formal name as registered in an official (government) registry, but which name might not be commonly used. Particularly used in countries with a law system based on Napoleonic law.

1 SRCH Search Type Uses

A name intended for use in searching or matching.
2  SNDX Soundex

A name spelled according to the SoundEx algorithm.
2  PHON phonetic

The name as understood by the data enterer, i.e. a close approximation of a phonetic spelling of the name, not based on a phonetic algorithm.

 2.21.3.1XML Representation

use is represented by the XML attribute use whose value, if present, must be 0 or more valid values from the EntityNameUse domain (Concept Domain EntityNameUse. ValueSet OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.1.11.15913. CodeSystem "", OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.5.45, Owner: HL7) separated by whitespace.

 2.21.4Valid Time : IVL<TS>

Definition:      An interval of time specifying the time during which the name is or was used for the entity. This accomodates the fact that people change names for people, places and things.

 2.21.4.1XML Representation

validTime is represented by 0 or more XML elements validTime each of which must be a valid IVL<TS>.

 2.21.5Examples

See the examples in Examples, Examples and Examples.

 2.22Person Name (PN) specializes EN -->

Definition:      A name for a person. A sequence of name parts, such as given name or family name, prefix, suffix, etc. PN differs from EN because the qualifier type cannot include LS (Legal Status).

Components of Person Name
Name Type Description
use DSET<CS> A set of codes advising a system or user which name in a set of like names to select for a given purpose. A name without specific use code might be a default name useful for any purpose, but a name with a specific use code would be preferred for that respective purpose.
validTime IVL<TS> An interval of time specifying the time during which the name is or was used for the entity. This accomodates the fact that people change names for people, places and things.
 2.22.1XML Representation

PN is represented by an XML element whose name is determined by the context in which it is used. The element has attributes and child elements as described in the template and the sub-sections below.

 2.22.2template
<!-- type PN -->
<x
   nullFlavor = ( NI | INV | OTH | NINF | PINF | UNC | DER | UNK | ASKU | NAV | QS | NASK | TRC | MSK | NA )
   flavorId = ST*
   updateMode = (A | D | R | AR | N | U | K)
   use = CS*
   >
   Content: ( (delimiter | family | given | prefix | suffix | #PCDATA)*, validTime )
</x>

Any non whitespace text in the PN content is interpreted as ENXP parts with a null partType. Refer to the the Formatting Name section (2.23.1.4) in Abstract Data Types Specification for full details on interpretation of PN content.

 2.22.3Use : DSET<CS> (inherited from EN)

Definition:      A set of codes advising a system or user which name in a set of like names to select for a given purpose. A name without specific use code might be a default name useful for any purpose, but a name with a specific use code would be preferred for that respective purpose.

 2.22.4XML Representation

use is represented by the XML attribute use whose value, if present, must be 0 or more valid values from the EntityNameUse domain (Concept Domain EntityNameUse. ValueSet OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.1.11.15913. CodeSystem "", OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.5.45, Owner: HL7) separated by whitespace.

 2.22.5Valid Time : IVL<TS> (inherited from EN)

Definition:      An interval of time specifying the time during which the name is or was used for the entity. This accomodates the fact that people change names for people, places and things.

 2.22.6XML Representation

validTime is represented by 0 or more XML elements validTime each of which must be a valid IVL<TS>.

 2.22.7Examples

A very simple encoding of "Adam A. Everyman" would be:

 2.22.7.1example
<name>
   <given>Adam</given>
   <given>A.</given>
   <family>Everyman</family>
</name>

None of the special qualifiers need to be mentioned if they are unknown or irrelevant. The next example shows extensive use of multiple given names, prefixes, suffixes, for academic degrees, nobility titles, vorvoegsels ("van"), and professional designations.

 2.22.7.2example
<name>
   <prefix qualifier='AC'>Dr. phil. </prefix>
   <given>Regina</given>
   <given>Johanna</given>
   <given>Maria</given>
   <prefix qualifier='NB'>Gr&auml;fin </prefix>
   <family qualifier='BR'>Hochheim</family>-<family qualifier='SP'>Weilenfels</family>
   <suffix qualifier='PR'>NCFSA</suffix>
</name>

The following example shows a Japanese name in the three forms: ideographic (Kanji), syllabic (Hiragana), and alphabetic (Romaji).

 2.22.7.3example
<name use='IDE'>
   <family>木村</family>
   <given>道男</given>
</name>
<name use="SYL">
   <family>きむら</family>
   <given>みちお</given>
</name>
<name use="ABC">
   <family>KIMURA</family>
   <given>MICHIO</given>
</name>
 2.23Organization Name (ON) specializes EN -->

Definition:      A name for an organization. A sequence of name parts.

Components of Organization Name
Name Type Description
use DSET<CS> A set of codes advising a system or user which name in a set of like names to select for a given purpose. A name without specific use code might be a default name useful for any purpose, but a name with a specific use code would be preferred for that respective purpose.
validTime IVL<TS> An interval of time specifying the time during which the name is or was used for the entity. This accomodates the fact that people change names for people, places and things.
 2.23.1XML Representation

ON is represented by an XML element whose name is determined by the context in which it is used. The element has attributes and child elements as described in the template and the sub-sections below.

 2.23.2template
<!-- type ON -->
<x
   nullFlavor = ( NI | INV | OTH | NINF | PINF | UNC | DER | UNK | ASKU | NAV | QS | NASK | TRC | MSK | NA )
   flavorId = ST*
   updateMode = (A | D | R | AR | N | U | K)
   use = CS*
   >
   Content: ( (delimiter | prefix | suffix | #PCDATA)*, validTime )
</x>

Any non whitespace text in the ON content is interpreted as ENXP parts with a null partType. Refer to the the Formatting Name section (2.23.1.4) in Abstract Data Types Specification for full details on interpretation of ON content.

 2.23.3Use : DSET<CS> (inherited from EN)

Definition:      A set of codes advising a system or user which name in a set of like names to select for a given purpose. A name without specific use code might be a default name useful for any purpose, but a name with a specific use code would be preferred for that respective purpose.

 2.23.4XML Representation

use is represented by the XML attribute use whose value, if present, must be 0 or more valid values from the EntityNameUse domain (Concept Domain EntityNameUse. ValueSet OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.1.11.15913. CodeSystem "", OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.5.45, Owner: HL7) separated by whitespace.

 2.23.5Valid Time : IVL<TS> (inherited from EN)

Definition:      An interval of time specifying the time during which the name is or was used for the entity. This accomodates the fact that people change names for people, places and things.

 2.23.6XML Representation

validTime is represented by 0 or more XML elements validTime each of which must be a valid IVL<TS>.

 2.23.7Examples

The following is the name of HL7 with the legal status "Inc." as a distinguished name part:

 2.23.7.1example
<name>Health Level Seven, <suffix qualifier='LS'>Inc.</suffix></name>
 2.24Trivial Name (TN) specializes EN -->

Definition:      A restriction of entity name that is effectively a simple string used for a simple name for things and places.

Components of Trivial Name
Name Type Description
use DSET<CS> A set of codes advising a system or user which name in a set of like names to select for a given purpose. A name without specific use code might be a default name useful for any purpose, but a name with a specific use code would be preferred for that respective purpose.
validTime IVL<TS> An interval of time specifying the time during which the name is or was used for the entity. This accomodates the fact that people change names for people, places and things.
 2.24.1XML Representation

TN is represented by an XML element whose name is determined by the context in which it is used. The element has attributes and child elements as described in the template and the sub-sections below.

 2.24.2template
<!-- type TN -->
<x
   nullFlavor = ( NI | INV | OTH | NINF | PINF | UNC | DER | UNK | ASKU | NAV | QS | NASK | TRC | MSK | NA )
   flavorId = ST*
   updateMode = (A | D | R | AR | N | U | K)
   use = CS*
   >
   Content: ( #PCDATA, validTime )
</x>
 2.24.3Use : DSET<CS> (inherited from EN)

Definition:      A set of codes advising a system or user which name in a set of like names to select for a given purpose. A name without specific use code might be a default name useful for any purpose, but a name with a specific use code would be preferred for that respective purpose.

 2.24.4XML Representation

use is represented by the XML attribute use whose value, if present, must be 0 or more valid values from the EntityNameUse domain (Concept Domain EntityNameUse. ValueSet OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.1.11.15913. CodeSystem "", OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.5.45, Owner: HL7) separated by whitespace.

 2.24.5Valid Time : IVL<TS> (inherited from EN)

Definition:      An interval of time specifying the time during which the name is or was used for the entity. This accomodates the fact that people change names for people, places and things.

 2.24.6XML Representation

validTime is represented by 0 or more XML elements validTime each of which must be a valid IVL<TS>.

 2.24.7Examples

The following is the organization name, "Health Level Seven, Inc." in a simple string form:

 2.24.7.1example
<name>Health Level Seven, Inc.</name>
 2.25Quantity (QTY) -->

Definition:     QTY is an abstract generalization for all data types (1) whose value set has an order relation (less-or-equal) and (2) where difference is defined in all of the data type's totally ordered value subsets. The quantity type abstraction is needed in defining certain other types, such as the interval and the probability distribution.

The Data Types Abstract Specification defines a diff property of a data type (not data value) that is the data type of the difference value between two data values of the quantity type. By default the diff property equals the same data type, but it may be overridden by a specialization of QTY. For instance, the difference between two TS values has the data type PQ (in the dimension of elapsed time.)

 2.25.1XML Representation

QTY is an abstract data type and cannot be used directly in the XML instance, so it has no XML representation. Instead, a specific descendent type must be used.

 2.25.2Original Text : ED

Definition:      The text as seen and/or selected by the user who entered the data.

Original text can be used in a structured user interface to capture what the user saw as a representation of the code on the data input screen, or in a situation where the user dictates or directly enters text, it is the text entered or uttered by the user. It is valid to use the CD data type to store only the text that the user entered or uttered. In this situation, original text will exist without a code. In a situation where the value is assigned sometime after the text was entered, originalText is the text or phrase used as the basis for assigning the code.

The originalText is not a substitute for a valid value. If the actual value of the QTY is not valid, then the QTY SHALL be null, irrespective of whether originalText has a value or not.

 2.25.2.1XML Representation

originalText is represented by the XML element originalText which, if present, must be a valid ED.

 2.26Integer Number (INT) specializes QTY -->

Definition:      Integer numbers (-1,0,1,2, 100, 3398129, etc.) are precise numbers that are results of counting and enumerating. Integer numbers are discrete, the set of integers is infinite but countable. No arbitrary limit is imposed on the range of integer numbers. Two NULL flavors are defined for the positive and negative infinity.

 2.26.1XML Representation

INT is represented by both Element and Attribute forms. In the Element form, the name of the element is determined by the context in which it is used. The element has attributes as described in the template and the sub-sections below.

 2.26.2template
<!-- type INT -->
<x
   nullFlavor = ( NI | INV | OTH | NINF | PINF | UNC | DER | UNK | ASKU | NAV | QS | NASK | TRC | MSK | NA )
   flavorId = ST*
   updateMode = (A | D | R | AR | N | U | K)
   value = xs:integer
   >
   Content: ( originalText )
</x>

XML instances may carry either a nullFlavor or a value, but not both.

The Attribute form of INT is used when properties of other data types have type INT. The name of the attribute is determined by the context in which it is used. The attribute value is the integer value.

 2.26.3Original Text : ED (inherited from QTY)

Definition:      The text as seen and/or selected by the user who entered the data.

 2.26.4XML Representation

originalText is represented by the XML element originalText which, if present, must be a valid ED.

 2.27Real Number (REAL) specializes QTY -->

Definition:      Fractional numbers. Typically used whenever quantities are measured, estimated, or computed from other real numbers. The typical representation is decimal, where the number of significant decimal digits is known as the precision. Real numbers are needed beyond integers whenever quantities of the real world are measured, estimated, or computed from other real numbers. The term "Real number" in this specification is used to mean that fractional values are covered without necessarily implying the full set of the mathematical real numbers.

 2.27.1XML Representation

REAL is represented by both Element and Attribute forms. In the Element form, the name of the element is determined by the context in which it is used. The element has attributes as described in the template and the sub-sections below.

 2.27.2template
<!-- type REAL -->
<x
   nullFlavor = ( NI | INV | OTH | NINF | PINF | UNC | DER | UNK | ASKU | NAV | QS | NASK | TRC | MSK | NA )
   flavorId = ST*
   updateMode = (A | D | R | AR | N | U | K)
   value = Union of (xs:decimal xs:double)
   >
   Content: ( originalText )
</x>

XML instances may carry either a nullFlavor or a value, but not both.

The Attribute form of REAL is used when properties of other data types have type REAL. The name of the attribute is determined by the context in which it is used. The attribute value is the real value.

For both the element and Attribute form, the value of the REAL as represented must conform to either of the XML Schema data types decimal or double.

 2.27.3Original Text : ED (inherited from QTY)

Definition:      The text as seen and/or selected by the user who entered the data.

 2.27.4XML Representation

originalText is represented by the XML element originalText which, if present, must be a valid ED.

 2.28Physical Quantity (PQ) specializes QTY -->

Definition:      A dimensioned quantity expressing the result of a measurement act.

Components of Physical Quantity
Name Type Description
value REAL The magnitude of the quantity measured in terms of the unit.
unit CS The unit of measure specified in the Unified Code for Units of Measure (UCUM) [].
originalText ED The text as seen and/or selected by the user who entered the data.
codingRationale CS CodingRationale provides a reason why a particular PQ has been provided, either as the root concept or as one of the translations.
translation PQR An alternative representation of the same physical quantity expressed in a different unit, of a different unit code system and possibly with a different value.
 2.28.1XML Representation

PQ is represented by an XML element whose name is determined by the context in which it is used. The element has attributes and child elements as described in the template and the sub-sections below.

 2.28.2template
<!-- type PQ -->
<x
   nullFlavor = ( NI | INV | OTH | NINF | PINF | UNC | DER | UNK | ASKU | NAV | QS | NASK | TRC | MSK | NA )
   flavorId = ST*
   updateMode = (A | D | R | AR | N | U | K)
   value = REAL
   unit = CS
   codingRationale = CS
   >
   Content: ( originalText, translation* )
</x>

XML instances may carry either a nullFlavor or a value, but not both. The unit attribute must be populated if the value attribute is present, and cannot be present when the value attribute is not present.

 2.28.3Value : REAL

Definition:      The magnitude of the quantity measured in terms of the unit.

 2.28.3.1XML Representation

value is represented by the XML attribute value whose value, if present, must be a valid REAL.

 2.28.4Unit of Measure : CS

Definition:      The unit of measure specified in the Unified Code for Units of Measure (UCUM) [].

More detail on the Unified Code for Units of Measure, and example tables of units commonly seen in practice with HL7 are provided in an appendix of the Data Types Abstract Specification.

The default unit of measure is 1 (the "unity").

 2.28.4.1XML Representation

unit is represented by the XML attribute unit whose value, if present, must be a valid unit of measure as defined in UCUM [].

 2.28.5Original Text : ED (inherited from QTY)

Definition:      The text as seen and/or selected by the user who entered the data.

 2.28.6XML Representation

originalText is represented by the XML element originalText which, if present, must be a valid ED.

 2.28.7CodingRationale : CS

Definition:      CodingRationale provides a reason why a particular PQ has been provided, either as the root concept or as one of the translations.

Concept Domain CodingRationale. ValueSet OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.11.19250. CodeSystem "CodingRationale", OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.5.1074, Owner: HL7
lvl code name definition
1 O Original

Originally produced code
1 P Post-coded

Post-coded from free text source
1 R Required

Required standard code for HL7
1 OR Original & Required

Originally produced code, required by HL7
1 PR Post-coded & Required

Post-coded from free text source, required by HL7
 2.28.7.1XML Representation

codingRationale is represented by the XML attribute codingRationale whose value, if present, must be taken from the codingRationale domain as specified above.

 2.28.8Translation : PQR

Definition:      An alternative representation of the same physical quantity expressed in a different unit, of a different unit code system and possibly with a different value.

 2.28.8.1XML Representation

translation is represented by 0 or more XML elements translation each of which must be a valid PQR.

 2.28.9Examples

This example shows a value of 22.35 millimoles per milliliter.

 2.28.9.1example
<value value='22.35' unit='mmol/mL'/>

The final example shows a value of 1.77 meters as well as a translation into inches.

 2.28.9.2example
<value value='1.77' unit='m'>
   <translation value='69.7' code='[in_I]'
      codeSystem='2.16.840.1.113883.19.6.8' codeSystemName='UCUM'/>
</value>
 2.29Physical Quantity Representation (PQR) specializes CV -->

Definition:      A representation of a physical quantity in a unit from any code system. Used to show alternative representation for a physical quantity.

Components of Physical Quantity Representation
Name Type Description
value REAL The magnitude of the measurement value in terms of the unit specified in the code.
code ST The plain code symbol or expression defined by the code system. For example, "784.0" is the code symbol of the ICD-9 code "784.0" for headache.
codeSystem UID Specifies the code system that defines the code.
codeSystemName ST A common name of the coding system.
codeSystemVersion ST If applicable, a version descriptor defined specifically for the given code system.
valueSet OID The value set that applied when this CD was coded.
valueSetVersion ST The version of the valueSet that applied when this CD was coded.
displayName ST A name, title, or representation for the code as it exists in the code system identified by the value of codeSystem. This must be a valid human readable representation of the code as it exists in the code system at the time of data entry. Normally, this would be the human readable representation of the code that the sending system shows to its users. The displayName is included so that an unaided human interpreter of a code value has a human readable description of what the code meant within the code system at the time of data entry.
originalText ED The text as seen and/or selected by the user who entered the data.
codingRationale CS CodingRationale provides a reason why a particular CD has been provided, either as the root concept or as one of the translations.

This is an extension of the coded value data type.

 2.29.1XML Representation

PQR is represented by an XML element whose name is determined by the context in which it is used. The element has attributes and child elements as described in the template and the sub-sections below.

 2.29.2template
<!-- type PQR -->
<x
   nullFlavor = ( NI | INV | OTH | NINF | PINF | UNC | DER | UNK | ASKU | NAV | QS | NASK | TRC | MSK | NA )
   flavorId = ST*
   updateMode = (A | D | R | AR | N | U | K)
   code = ST
   codeSystem = UID
   codeSystemName = ST
   codeSystemVersion = ST
   valueSet = OID
   valueSetVersion = ST
   displayName = ST
   codingRationale = CS
   value = REAL
   >
   Content: ( originalText )
</x>
 2.29.3Value : REAL

Definition:      The magnitude of the measurement value in terms of the unit specified in the code.

 2.29.3.1XML Representation

value is represented by the XML attribute value whose value, if present, must be a valid REAL.

 2.29.4Code : ST (inherited from CD)

Definition:      The plain code symbol or expression defined by the code system. For example, "784.0" is the code symbol of the ICD-9 code "784.0" for headache.

 2.29.5XML Representation

code is represented by the XML attribute code whose value, if present, must be a valid xs:token with no internal whitespace.

 2.29.6Code System : UID (inherited from CD)

Definition:      Specifies the code system that defines the code.

 2.29.7XML Representation

codeSystem is represented by the XML attribute codeSystem whose value, if present, must be a valid UID.

 2.29.8Code System Name : ST (inherited from CD)

Definition:      A common name of the coding system.

 2.29.9XML Representation

codeSystemName is represented by the XML attribute codeSystem whose value, if present, must be a valid ST.

 2.29.10Code System Version : ST (inherited from CD)

Definition:      If applicable, a version descriptor defined specifically for the given code system.

 2.29.11XML Representation

codeSystemVersion is represented by the XML attribute codeSystemVersion whose value, if present, must be a valid ST.

 2.29.12Value Set : OID (inherited from CD)

Definition:      The value set that applied when this CD was coded.

 2.29.13XML Representation

valueSet is represented by the XML attribute valueSet whose value, if present, must be a valid OID.

 2.29.14Value Set Version : ST (inherited from CD)

Definition:      The version of the valueSet that applied when this CD was coded.

 2.29.15XML Representation

valueSetVersion is represented by the XML attribute valueSetVersion whose value, if present, must be a valid ST.

 2.29.16Display Name : ST (inherited from CD)

Definition:      A name, title, or representation for the code as it exists in the code system identified by the value of codeSystem. This must be a valid human readable representation of the code as it exists in the code system at the time of data entry. Normally, this would be the human readable representation of the code that the sending system shows to its users. The displayName is included so that an unaided human interpreter of a code value has a human readable description of what the code meant within the code system at the time of data entry.

 2.29.17XML Representation

displayName is represented by the XML attribute displayName whose value, if present, must be a valid ST.

 2.29.18Original Text : ED (inherited from CD)

Definition:      The text as seen and/or selected by the user who entered the data.

 2.29.19XML Representation

originalText is represented by the XML element originalText which, if present, must be a valid ED.

 2.29.20CodingRationale : CS (inherited from CD)

Definition:      CodingRationale provides a reason why a particular CD has been provided, either as the root concept or as one of the translations.

 2.29.21XML Representation

codingRationale is represented by the XML attribute codingRationale whose value, if present, must be a valid value from the CodingRationale (Concept Domain CodingRationale. ValueSet OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.11.19250. CodeSystem "CodingRationale", OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.5.1074, Owner: HL7 Concept Domain CodingRationale. ValueSet OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.11.19250. CodeSystem "CodingRationale", OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.5.1074, Owner: HL7) separated by whitespace.

 2.29.22Examples

See the example using PQ.translation in Examples.

 2.30Monetary Amount (MO) specializes QTY -->

Definition:      A monetary amount is a quantity expressing the amount of money in some currency. Currencies are the units in which monetary amounts are denominated in different economic regions. While the monetary amount is a single kind of quantity (money) the exchange rates between the different units are variable. This is the principle difference between physical quantity and monetary amounts, and the reason why currency units are not physical units.

Components of Monetary Amount
Name Type Description
value REAL The magnitude of the monetary amount in terms of the currency unit.
currency CS The currency unit as defined in ISO 4217.
originalText ED The text as seen and/or selected by the user who entered the data.
 2.30.1XML Representation

MO is represented by an XML element whose name is determined by the context in which it is used. The element has attributes as described in the template and the sub-sections below.

 2.30.2template
<!-- type MO -->
<x
   nullFlavor = ( NI | INV | OTH | NINF | PINF | UNC | DER | UNK | ASKU | NAV | QS | NASK | TRC | MSK | NA )
   flavorId = ST*
   updateMode = (A | D | R | AR | N | U | K)
   value = REAL
   currency = CS
   >
   Content: ( originalText )
</x>
 2.30.3Value : REAL

Definition:      The magnitude of the monetary amount in terms of the currency unit.

 2.30.3.1XML Representation

value is represented by the XML attribute value whose value, if present, must be a valid REAL.

 2.30.4Currency : CS

Definition:      The currency unit as defined in ISO 4217.

Concept Domain Currency. ValueSet OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.11.17388. CodeSystem "Currency", OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.5.1058, Owner: ISO 4217
lvl code name definition
1 ARS Argentine Peso

Argentine Peso, monetary currency of Argentina
1 AUD Australian Dollar

Australian Dollar, monetary currency of Australia
1 THB Baht

Baht, monetary currency of Thailand
1 BRL Brazilian Real

Brazilian Real, monetary currency of Brazil
1 CAD Canadian Dollar

Canadian Dollar, monetary currency of Canada
1 DEM Deutsche Mark

Deutsche Mark, monetary currency of Germany
1 EUR Euro

Euro, monetary currency of European Union
1 FRF French Franc

French Franc, monetary currency of France
1 INR Indian Rupee

Indian Rupee, monetary currency of India
1 TRL Lira

Lira, monetary currency of Turkey
1 FIM Markka

Markka, monetary currency of Finland
1 MXN Mexican Nuevo Peso

Mexican Nuevo Peso, monetary currency of Mexico
1 NLG Netherlands Guilder

Netherlands Guilder, monetary currency of Netherlands
1 NZD New Zealand Dollar

New Zealand Dollar, monetary currency of New Zealand
1 PHP Philippine Peso

Philippine Peso, monetary currency of Philippines
1 GBP Pound Sterling

Pound Sterling, monetary currency of United Kingdom
1 ZAR Rand

Rand, monetary currency of South Africa
1 RUR Russian Ruble

Russian Ruble, monetary currency of Russian Federation
1 ILS Shekel

Shekel, monetary currency of Israel
1 ESP Spanish Peseta

Spanish Peseta, monetary currency of Spain
1 CHF Swiss Franc

Swiss Franc, monetary currency of Switzerland
1 TWD Taiwan Dollar

Taiwan Dollar, monetary currency of Taiwan
1 USD US Dollar

US Dollar, monetary currency of United States
1 CLF Unidades de Formento

Unidades de Formento, monetary currency of Chile
1 KRW Won

Won, monetary currency of Korea (South)
1 JPY Yen

Yen, monetary currency of Japan
1 CNY Yuan Renminbi

Yuan Renminbi, monetary currency of China

This table only shows a representative subset of the codes defined by ISO 4217. All codes from ISO 4127 are valid for this attribute.

 2.30.4.1XML Representation

currency is represented by the XML attribute value whose value, if present, must be a valid currency code as defined by ISO 4217.

 2.30.5Original Text : ED (inherited from QTY)

Definition:      The text as seen and/or selected by the user who entered the data.

 2.30.6XML Representation

originalText is represented by the XML element originalText which, if present, must be a valid ED.

 2.30.7Examples

This example shows an amount of 10 Euros.

 2.30.7.1example
<amt value='10' currency='EUR'/>
 2.31Ratio (RTO) specializes QTY -->

Definition:      A quantity constructed as the quotient of a numerator quantity divided by a denominator quantity. Common factors in the numerator and denominator are not automatically cancelled out. RTO supports titers (e.g., "1:128") and other quantities produced by laboratories that truly represent ratios. Ratios are not simply "structured numerics", particularly blood pressure measurements (e.g. "120/60") are not ratios. In many cases REAL should be used instead of RTO.

Note: This data type is not defined to generally represent rational numbers. It is used only if common factors in numerator and denominator are not supposed to cancel out. This is only rarely the case. For observation values, ratios occur almost exclusively with titers.

Components of Ratio
Name Type Description
originalText ED The text as seen and/or selected by the user who entered the data.
numerator QTY The quantity that is being divided in the ratio. The default is the integer number 1 (one).
denominator QTY The quantity that devides the numerator in the ratio. The default is the integer number 1 (one). The denominator must not be zero.

The default value for both numerator and denominator is the integer number 1 (one.) The denominator may not be zero.

Note: This data type is defined as a generic data type but discussed in the context of the other quantity-related data types. The reason for defining RTO as a generic data type is so that it can be constrained precisely as to what the numerator and denominator types should be.

 2.31.1XML Representation

RTO is represented by an XML element whose name is determined by the context in which it is used. The element has attributes as described in the template and the sub-sections below.

 2.31.2template
<!-- type RTO -->
<x
   nullFlavor = ( NI | INV | OTH | NINF | PINF | UNC | DER | UNK | ASKU | NAV | QS | NASK | TRC | MSK | NA )
   flavorId = ST*
   updateMode = (A | D | R | AR | N | U | K)
   >
   Content: ( originalText, numerator, denominator )
</x>

Both numerator and denominator are required for a ratio or else it has a NULL value. (Note that both numerator and denominator have 1 (one) as their default.)

XML instances must use the xsi:type schema type assertion mechanism to specify the particular restriction of QTY being used for numerator and denominator respectively. The types may be asserted on the numerator or denominator directly (as in rto1 and rto3), or the combined type may be asserted on the element representing the RTO value (as in rto2). In the later case, the type name to be asserted follows the rules described in Use of attributes from XML specifications.

 2.31.3Original Text : ED (inherited from QTY)

Definition:      The text as seen and/or selected by the user who entered the data.

 2.31.4XML Representation

originalText is represented by the XML element originalText which, if present, must be a valid ED.

 2.31.5Numerator : QTY

Definition:      The quantity that is being divided in the ratio. The default is the integer number 1 (one).

 2.31.5.1XML Representation

numerator is represented by the XML element numerator which, if present, must be valid instance of a descendant of QTY.

 2.31.6Denominator : QTY

Definition:      The quantity that devides the numerator in the ratio. The default is the integer number 1 (one). The denominator must not be zero.

 2.31.6.1XML Representation

denominator is represented by the XML element denominator which, if present, must be valid instance of a descendant of QTY.

 2.31.7Examples

The first example shows a ratio of INTs, where the types of the numerator and demoninator are asserted individually.

 2.31.7.1example
<unitQuanity>
   <numerator value='1' xsi:type='INT'/>
   <denominator value='64' xsi:type='INT'/>
</unitQuanity>

The second example shows a ratio of MO and PQ where the types of the numerator and demoninator are asserted on the element representing the RTO value.

 2.31.7.2example
<unitPriceAmount xsi:type='RTO_MO_PQ'>
   <numerator value='1.15' currency='USD'/>
   <denominator value='1' unit='[gal_us]'/>
</unitPriceAmount>

The final example shows a ratio of PQs, where the types of the numerator and demoninator are asserted individually.

 2.31.7.3example
<maxDoseQuantity>
   <numerator xsi:type='PQ' value='25' unit='mg'/>
   <denominator xsi:type='PQ' value='5' unit='mL'/>
</maxDoseQuantity>
 2.32Point in Time (TS) specializes QTY -->

Definition:      A quantity specifying a point on the axis of natural time. A point in time is most often represented as a calendar expression.

 2.32.1XML Representation

TS is represented by an XML element whose name is determined by the context in which it is used. The element has attributes as described in the template below. The format of the value attribute is described below.

 2.32.2template
<!-- type TS -->
<x
   nullFlavor = ( NI | INV | OTH | NINF | PINF | UNC | DER | UNK | ASKU | NAV | QS | NASK | TRC | MSK | NA )
   flavorId = ST*
   updateMode = (A | D | R | AR | N | U | K)
   value = ST
   >
   Content: ( originalText )
</x>

XML instances may carry either a nullFlavor or a value, but not both.

The value of a point in time is represented using the ISO 8601 compliant form traditionally in use with HL7. This is the form that has no decorating dashes, colons and no "T" between the date and time. In short, the syntax is "YYYYMMDDHHMMSS.UUUU[+|-ZZzz]" where digits can be omitted from the right side to express less precision. Common forms are "YYYYMMDD" and "YYYYMMDDHHMM", but the ability to truncate on the right side is not limited to these two variants. See the Data Types Abstract Specification for detail.

Note: This is not the W3C Schema form for dateTime. The W3C Schema time data types do not lend themselves as well to representing the varying precision as well as the simpler ISO 8601 variant that is well established in HL7.

 2.32.3Original Text : ED (inherited from QTY)

Definition:      The text as seen and/or selected by the user who entered the data.

 2.32.4XML Representation

originalText is represented by the XML element originalText which, if present, must be a valid ED.

 2.32.5Examples

This example shows April 7, 2000.

 2.32.5.1example
<effectiveTime value="20000407"/>

The next example shows 12:42 pm (in the time zone that is 8 hours before UTC) on September 21, 2005.

 2.32.5.2example
<effectiveTime value="200509211242-08"/>
 2.33Expression (EXPR) specializes QTY -->

Definition:      A generic data type extension used to specify an expression that can be used to derive the actual value of T given information taken from the context of use.

 2.33.1XML Representation

EXPR is represented by an XML element whose name is determined by the context in which it is used. The element has attributes as described in the template below. The format of the value attribute is described below.

 2.33.2template
<!-- type EXPR -->
<x
   {any attributes from T}
   >
   Content: ( {any elements from T}, expression )
</x>

The expression specifies how the value of type T can be evaluated. Either an expression or a value or both may be provided. It is at the discretion of the receiver of the information whether to evaluate the expression when the information is being processed. If no value is provided, then the value SHALL have a nullFlavor, whether or not an expression is provided. .

 2.33.3Expression : ED

Definition:      The definition of the expression that can be evaluated to generate the actual value.

The language of the expression SHALL be inferred from the mediatype of the content. If multiple translations are provided in the ED, the evaluator is free to choose whichever language is preferred; all translations SHALL specify the same outcome.

The language of the defines the forms that the expression property can take, how the information available in the context of the is made available within the features of the language, and how the language declares the new form of the value. Implementers are not required to implement any languages in order to claim conformance to this specification, but SHOULD declare what languages are supported in their conformance statements.

Known languages
Language Mediatype
OCL text/plain+ocl
Factor (see below) application/hl7-factor+xml
MathML application/mathml+xml

This is not a list of allowed expression languages, just a convenient summary of some types that may be encountered. If no supported language is found in the expression, then the outcome of the evaluation is NULL.

 2.33.3.1XML Representation

expression is represented by the XML element expression which, if present, must be a valid ED.

 2.33.4Examples

The following example shows an EXPR that specializes a PQ (specializes QTY). In this example, the addition of the nullFlavor="DER" indicates that the expression itself is derived.

 2.33.5example
					<value xsi:type="PQ" nullFlavor="DER">
						<expression value="Encounter.effectiveTime.low - Encounter.location.time.low"/>
					</value>
 3Generic Data Types

The Data Types Abstract Specification defines generic types, also called "parameterized types" (UML), "generics" (ADA) or "templates" (C++). Generic types are incomplete types with parameters such that they define actual types (sometimes called "instantiated" types) when their parameters are specified. For example, a LIST is a generic sequence of any values of a parameter type T. Given this generic type we can specify specific types such as LIST<CE> as sequences of codes or LIST<PQ> for a sequences of physical quantities.

The Data Types Abstract Specification specifies two different kinds of generic types, "generic collections" and "generic type extensions". Generic collections specify sets, sequences or other groups of data values. Generic type extensions provide extensions to normal types that are of general use, such as a valid-time for a "history item" or a probability for an "uncertain value".

In this XML specification, however, we will present these two kinds of types together. The reason is that enumerated collection types do not exist in the common use of XML. Instead it is common practice in XML to represent enumerated collections as a sequence of XML elements with the same name (repeated element). Therefore we define all such enumerated collection types as generic type extensions of their element type. For example, instead of having an XML element that stands for a whole BAG, we have generic type extension for bag-item (BXIT) so that the XML-element of type BAG is defined in the schema as a bag-item that can repeat.

 3.1Discrete Set (DSET) -->

Definition:      A value that contains other distinct values in no particular order.

NOTE: The abstract data types define an abstract SET with two concrete types DSET (Discrete Set) and QSET (Continuous Set). This type is the Discrete Set. Continuous Sets (QSETs) are represented using the GTS type.

Exceptional values (NULL-values) can not be elements of a discrete set.

The empty set is a set without any elements. The empty set is a proper set value, not an exceptional value (NULL-value).

Discrete Sets are a concrete specialization of the Collection (COLL) type defined in the Abstract Data Types. Because the Collection type is abstract, no concrete representation is required. However in the case where the context of use does not make clear whether the collection is a Discrete Set, List or a BAG, the Discrete Set must indicate it's type directly using the collectionType attribute. In addition, the Discrete Set may specify it's nullFlavor separately to the nullFlavor of it's elements using the collectionNullFlavor attribute.

 3.1.1XML Representation

DSET is represented by both Element and Attribute forms. In the Element form, DSET is represented by a sequence of XML elements, each of whose name is determined by the context in which it is used. The elements are of type T and SXCM, and have attributes and child elements as described for the data type T and also the attributes described below for SXCM. Only the first element may have the attributes "collectionType" and "collectionNullFlavor".

The Attribute form of DSET is used when properties of other data types have type DSET and T also has an Attribute form with no whitespace content. The name of the attribute is determined by the context in which it is used. The attribute value is a series of values of type T separated by whitespace.

 3.1.2Examples

The first example shows an Act with a discrete set of id's.

 3.1.2.1example
<act>
   <id root='2.16.840.1.113883.19' extension='123A45'/>
   <id root='343EA54F-D0E0-CE95-56C7-23108D6E25B8' extension='N8718349'/>
   ...
</act>

The next example shows an Act with a discrete set of reasonCode's.

 3.1.2.2example
<act>
   ...
   <reasonCode code='PHY' codeSystem='2.16.840.1.113883.19.5.8'
      codeSystemName='ActReason' displayName='Physician request'/>
   <reasonCode code='MEDNEC' codeSystem='2.16.840.1.113883.19.5.8'
      codeSystemName='ActReason' displayName='Medical Necessity'/>
   ...
</act>

The final example shows an Act with an effectiveTime that uses the intersect SXCM.operator.

 3.1.2.3example
<act>
   ...
   <effectiveTime xsi:type='IVL_TS'>
      <low value='20040204'/>
   </effectiveTime>
   <effectiveTime xsi:type='PIVL_TS' operator='A'>
      <phase>
         <center value='200402041200'/>
      </phase>
      <period value='1' unit='d'/>
   </effectiveTime>
   ...
</act>
 3.2Set Component (SXCM) -->

Definition:      An ITS-defined generic type extension for the base data type of a set, representing a component of a general set - either a discrete or continuous set. Other than for the attributes collectionType and collectionNullFlavor, its use is mainly for continuous value domains (QSET constructor, used with GTS). Discrete (enumerable) set components are the individual elements of the base data type.

Components of Set Component
Name Type Description
operator CS A code specifying whether the set component is included (union) or excluded (set-difference) from the set, or other set operations with the current set component and the set as constructed from the representation stream up to the current point.
collectionNullFlavor CS An exceptional value expressing, for the discrete set, missing information and possibly the reason why the information is missing.
collectionType CS The type of collection, for when the type of the collection is not fixed by the context of use.
 3.2.1XML Representation

SXCM is represented by an XML element whose name is determined by the context in which it is used. SXCM has all the attributes and child elements described for the Element form of T and adds an XML attribute operator as described in the template and sub-sections below.

 3.2.2template
<!-- type SXCM -->
<x
   nullFlavor = ( NI | INV | OTH | NINF | PINF | UNC | DER | UNK | ASKU | NAV | QS | NASK | TRC | MSK | NA )
   flavorId = ST*
   updateMode = (A | D | R | AR | N | U | K)
   {any attributes from T}
   operator = (I | E | A | H | P) : I
   collectionNullFlavor = ( NI | INV | OTH | NINF | PINF | UNC | DER | UNK | ASKU | NAV | QS | NASK | TRC | MSK | NA )
   collectionType = DSET | LIST | BAG
   >
   Content: ( {any elements from T} )
</x>
 3.2.3Operator : CS

Definition:      A code specifying whether the set component is included (union) or excluded (set-difference) from the set, or other set operations with the current set component and the set as constructed from the representation stream up to the current point.

Concept Domain SetOperator. ValueSet OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.1.11.17416. CodeSystem "", OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.11.17416, Owner: HL7
lvl code name definition
1 H convex hull

Form the convex hull with the value. The convex hull is defined over ordered domains and is the smallest contiguous superset (interval) that of all the operand sets.

1 E exclude

Form the set-difference with this value, i.e., exclude this element or set from the resulting set.
1 I include

Form the union with this value, i.e., include this element or set in the resulting set.
1 A intersect

Form the intersection with the value.
1 P periodic hull

Form the periodic hull with the value. The periodic hull is defined over ordered domains and is the periodic set that contains all contiguous supersets of pairs of intervals generated by the operand periodic intervals.

 3.2.3.1XML Representation

operator is represented as the XML attribute operator, whose value, if present, must be a valid code from the SetOperator domain (Concept Domain SetOperator. ValueSet OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.1.11.17416. CodeSystem "", OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.11.17416, Owner: HL7). The default value is I.

 3.2.4Collection NullFlavor : CS

Definition:      An exceptional value expressing, for the discrete set, missing information and possibly the reason why the information is missing.

Each item in the DSET is represented directly in the instance, but the DSET itself is not represented. In a few cases, the difference between a null DSET, and a non-null DSET that contains a single null item is significant (e.g. "No phone numbers known" vs "no home phone number known"). In these cases, the attribute collectionNullFlavor may be used to distinguish between the nullFlavor of the DSET and the item. The collectionNullFlavor attribute may only be used on the first element of the DSET. An element with only a collectionNullFlavor attribute and no other attributes or elements is not considered to be a member of the DSET, but simply to carry the nullFlavor of the DSET.

Note that while a proper DSET may not contain null values, null DSETs may contain null values. Whether a collectionNullFlavor attribute exists or not, the presence of an element with a nullFlavor implies that the DSET is null.

Backwards Compatibility Note: In ITS 1, when a collection contains a single item with a nullFlavor, it is unknown whether the the collection has a null item, or whether the collection itself is null.

 3.2.4.1XML Representation

collectionNullFlavor is represented by the XML attribute collectionNullFlavor whose value, if present, must be a valid value from the NullFlavor domain (Concept Domain NullFlavor. ValueSet OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.11.10609. CodeSystem "NullFlavor", OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.5.1008, Owner: HL7).

 3.2.5Collection Type : CS

Definition:      The type of collection, for when the type of the collection is not fixed by the context of use.

The collectionType SHALL be populated when the context of use does not fix the collection type. The collectionType SHALL NOT disagree with the context of use. The collectionType SHALL not be populated on continuous sets.

Backwards Compatibility Note: Prior to data types R2, the context of use always specified the type of collection. If the exact type is unknown and unspecified, the collection should be interpreted as a BAG.

 3.2.5.1XML Representation

collectionType is represented by the XML attribute collectionType whose value, if present, must be one of "DSET", "LIST" or "BAG". In the case of a Discrete Set, the value SHALL be DSET.

 3.2.6Examples

See the examples using operator in Examples.

 3.3Sequence (LIST) -->

Definition:      A value that contains other discrete values in a defined sequence.

 3.3.1XML Representation

LISTs are a concrete specialization of the Collection (COLL) type defined in the Abstract Data Types. Because the Collection type is abstract, no concrete representation is required. However in the case where the context of use does not make clear whether the collection is a Discrete Set, List or a BAG, the LIST must indicate it's type directly using the collectionType attribute. In addition, the LIST may specify it's nullFlavor separately to the nullFlavor of it's elements using the collectionNullFlavor attribute.

LIST is represented by both Element and Attribute forms. In the Element form, the list is represented by a sequence of XML element s, each of whose name is determined by the context in which it is used. The elements have attributes and element children as described for the data type T, and also the collectionNullFlavor and collectionType attributes. Only the first element may have the attributes "collectionType" and "collectionNullFlavor".

The Attribute form of LIST is used when properties of other data types have type LIST and T also has an Attribute form which does not allow whitespace. The name of the attribute is determined by the context in which it is used. The attribute value is a series of values of type T separated by whitespace.

 3.3.2Collection NullFlavor : CS

Definition:      An exceptional value expressing, for the set, missing information and possibly the reason why the information is missing.

Each item in the LIST is represented directly in the instance, but the LIST itself is not represented. In a few cases, the difference between a null LIST, and a non-null LIST that contains a single null item is significant (e.g. "No phone numbers known" vs "no home phone number known"). In these cases, the attribute collectionNullFlavor may be used to distinguish between the nullFlavor of the LIST and the item. The collectionNullFlavor attribute may only be used on the first element of the LIST.
